The Middleborough Regional Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC or Middleborough Fire Department) is trained and equipped to respond to ammonia releases at CS Storage.
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
A Mechanical Integrity Audit of the Ammonia System was performed in August 2022, and a Process Hazard Analysis Update was conducted in July 2022.   The 2022 MI Audit and the 2022 PHA Update identified several areas where process improvements could improve the safety of the facility, including repair of damaged insulation, performance of non-destructive testing, replacement of system piping, updating of the existing preventative maintenance plan.

ican Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers guidance, and American Society of Mechanical Engineering (ASME) guidance.  Process verification takes place through design audits by trained personnel and/or certified consultants.  The schedule of such verifications is at least once every three years.
An off-site consequences analysis has been completed for the worst-case release scenario and an alternative release scenario to document the radius of impact (i.e., distance to toxic endpoint) for each scenario and the potential population, public receptors and environmental receptors that fall within the radius of impact for each scenario.
Preventative maintenance (PM) is an active part of CS Storage's daily operations.  PM is performed in accordance with OSHA-PSM and, in many cases; the process safety equipment PM schedule prescribed by CS Storage Foods exceeds recommended equipment maintenance schedules.  Ammonia detection sensors are present at two locations and are tested semi-annually. Relief valves are replaced by an ASME certified agent on a five-year schedule.
FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
In the last five years there have been no federal reportable releases that caused death, injury, hospitalization or property damage. 
THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
A process release would be detected by ammonia sensors located in process and perimeter locations.  A process release would also be detected by the employees through odor.  The ammonia sensors are tested semi-annually.  An alarm signal is triggered and would sound throughout the facility.  An alarm system auto-dialer is also activated if ammonia is detected.

In the event of a process release, the alarm system auto-dialer calls the facility maintenance department, which would in turn contact the Middleborough Department if any of the following conditions are present:
- Upon investigating the incident, CS Storage Foods determines that the release is severe enough to require response assistance; Re

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES AT YOUR FACILITY
It is CS Storage IV, Inc.’s policy to adhere to all applicable federal, State, and local laws.  The ammonia refrigeration process at CS Storage – Middleborough Facility has been designed and operates in compliance with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule, and applicable State and local codes and regulations. CS Storage has qualified engineering, operations, and maintenance personnel knowledgeable in the safe operation of ammonia refrigeration systems in direct responsibility of the process.  The process is also designed and operated in compliance with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's Process Safety Management (OSHA-PSM) rule.
Through its Emergency Action Plan (i.e., Contingency Plan) as required under OSHA PSM, CS Storage has emergency response procedures in place that comply with the Accidental Release Prevention Program (ARPP).
A DESCRIPTION OF YOUR FACILITY AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
CS Storage is a freezer warehouse facility primarily engaged in the storage of frozen foods.  The facility is a 150,530 sq. ft. Industrially zoned facility with a maximum inventory capacity of 20,037 pounds of anhydrous ammonia within the process.  The ARPP applicability threshold for anhydrous ammonia is 10,000 pounds.  As CS Storage anhydrous ammonia storage capacity exceeds this threshold, the facility is subject to the program and is required to prepare a RMP for this process.  The anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system at CS Storage is the only process that stores a substance in greater quantities than the ARPP applicability threshold.
The process is subject to Risk Management Program 3 because it is subject to OSHA-PSM provisions, and it is not eligible for Program 1.
